title: The Glory Returns
shortSummary: Ezekiel 43 describes the return of God's glory to the newly envisioned temple, symbolizing God's restored presence among His people. The chapter details the measurements and ordinances for the altar, emphasizing holiness, purification, and proper worship. This vision offers hope for Israel's future restoration and God's eternal dwelling with His people.
timeline: c. 593-571 BC - During the Babylonian exile, Ezekiel's prophetic visions of restoration

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet receiving visions of the temple and God's glory returning, tasked with communicating God's instructions to Israel.

keyCharacters.name: Man (Angel or Divine Messenger)
keyCharacters.description: The figure who guides Ezekiel through the vision and explains the significance of the temple and altar ordinances.

keyCharacters.name: Priests of the Seed of Zadok
keyCharacters.description: The Levitical priests specifically mentioned as those who will minister in the restored temple, emphasizing purity and faithfulness.

definitions.definition: The visible manifestation of God's presence and majesty, often associated with light and holiness.
An ancient unit of measurement roughly equivalent to 18 inches, used here to specify altar dimensions.
A sacrificial offering made to atone for unintentional sins and to purify the altar and people.
A priestly lineage descended from Zadok, considered faithful and authorized to serve in the temple.

outline.heading: The Return of God's Glory
outline.description: Ezekiel witnesses the glory of God entering the temple through the eastern gate, symbolizing God's presence returning to dwell with Israel forever.

outline.heading: God's Promise of Holiness and Presence
outline.description: God declares His throne and dwelling place in the temple, condemning past defilements and calling Israel to repentance and purity.

outline.heading: Instructions to Show the Temple Pattern
outline.description: Ezekiel is commanded to reveal the temple's design to Israel so they may be ashamed of their sins and faithfully observe God's laws.

outline.heading: Detailed Measurements of the Altar
outline.description: Precise dimensions and features of the altar are given, emphasizing order, holiness, and the importance of proper worship.

outline.heading: Ordinances for Altar Purification and Offerings
outline.description: God outlines the sacrificial procedures for consecrating the altar, including sin offerings and burnt offerings, highlighting the need for purification and dedication.

application: Recognize and honor God's holy presence in your life by pursuing purity and obedience in all areas.
Repent sincerely from past sins and defilements to experience God's restoration and fellowship.
Commit to learning and following God's instructions as revealed in Scripture, just as Israel was called to keep the temple ordinances.
Approach worship with reverence and dedication, understanding the significance of Christ's ultimate sacrifice that fulfills the altar's purpose.

keyVerses.text: And the glory of the LORD came into the house by the way of the gate whose prospect is toward the east.
keyVerses.significance: This verse marks the pivotal moment of God's presence returning to dwell with His people, symbolizing hope and restoration.

keyVerses.text: Son of man, the place of my throne, and the place of the soles of my feet, where I will dwell in the midst of the children of Israel for ever, and my holy name, shall the house of Israel no more defile, neither they, nor their kings, by their whoredom, nor by the carcases of their kings in their high places.
keyVerses.significance: God promises eternal presence and holiness, condemning past idolatry and defilement, emphasizing the need for purity.

keyVerses.text: Thou son of man, shew the house to the house of Israel, that they may be ashamed of their iniquities: and let them measure the pattern.
keyVerses.significance: God calls for self-examination and repentance through the revelation of His holy temple's design.

keyVerses.text: And when these days are expired, it shall be, that upon the eighth day, and so forward, the priests shall make your burnt offerings upon the altar, and your peace offerings; and I will accept you, saith the Lord GOD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse assures God's acceptance of Israel's worship after proper consecration, pointing forward to ongoing fellowship with God.
